Provision.Text: His Excellency the Governor General in Council, on the recommendation of the Minister of Transport, pursuant to sections 4.71a and 4.9b, paragraphs 7.6(1)(a)c and (b)c and section 7.7d of the Aeronautics Acte, hereby makes the annexed Canadian Aviation Security Regulations, 2012.

Subsection.Text: These Regulations are the principal means of supplementing the legislative framework set out in sections 4.7 to 4.87 of the Act. They are designed to enhance preparedness for acts or attempted acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation and to facilitate the detection of, prevention of, response to and recovery from acts or attempted acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation.
These Regulations are supplemented from time to time by other aviation security regulations and by security measures, interim orders, ministerial orders and emergency directions.

Section.Text: These Regulations are divided into 14 parts:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: Part 1 deals with screening authorities and the screening of persons and goods at aerodromes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: Part 2 deals with the CATSA security program;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: Part 3 deals with weapons, explosive substances and incendiary devices;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: Part 4 deals with security at aerodromes listed in Schedule 1;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: Part 5 deals with security at aerodromes listed in Schedule 2;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: Part 6 deals with security at aerodromes listed in Schedule 3 and at any other place designated by the Minister under subsection 6(1.1) of the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority Act;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: Part 7 deals with security at other aerodromes;

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: Part 8 deals with aircraft security;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: Part 9 is reserved;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: Part 10 is reserved;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: Part 11 deals with cargo and mail on flights departing from an aerodrome located in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: Part 12 deals with cargo on flights departing from a place outside Canada to an aerodrome located in Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: Part 13 sets out ministerial powers and duties; and

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: Part 14 sets out an administrative monetary penalty scheme for the contravention of certain provisions of these Regulations and the provisions of any security measure.

Section.Text: The following definitions apply in these Regulations.

Definition.Text: accepted cargo means any cargo in respect of which an air waybill or other similar control document is issued. (fret accepté)
Act means the Aeronautics Act. (Loi)

aerodrome security personnel means individuals who are employed by the operator of an aerodrome or by one of the operator’s contractors to prepare for, detect, prevent, respond to, and assist in the recovery from, acts or attempted acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation. (personnel de sûreté de l’aérodrome)
agency firearm has the same meaning as in section 1 of the Public Agents Firearms Regulations. (arme à feu d’agence)

baggage make-up area means an area of an air terminal building, or an area of a building at an aerodrome that is under an air carrier’s control, where checked baggage is stored. (zone de tri de bagages)
biometric template means a template generated by algorithms that encode an identifiable physiological or behavioural characteristic of a person. (modèle biométrique)
border services officer has the same meaning as in section 5 of the Preclearance Act, 2016. (agent des services frontaliers)
carry-on baggage means any baggage and personal belongings to which a person has or will have access on board an aircraft. (bagages de cabine)
CATSA means the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority established under subsection 5(1) of the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority Act. (ACSTA)
checked baggage means any baggage and personal belongings in respect of which a baggage tag is issued after the baggage and personal belongings are accepted for transportation. (bagages enregistrés)

combination code means a series or combination of numbers, letters or other characters that is assigned to a person by, or under the authority of, the operator of an aerodrome and that, when entered into mechanical or electronic equipment on or near a door, gate or other device, unlocks or releases the door, gate or other device and allows access to a restricted area. (code d’accès)

consolidated cargo means multiple cargo shipments that originate from more than one original shipper that are consolidated to form one shipment under the air waybill or similar control document. (fret groupé)
crew member means a person assigned to duty on an aircraft during flight time by the operator of the aircraft. (membre d’équipage)
defensive equipment means a baton or oleoresin capsicum spray, or both. (équipement défensif)
document of entitlement means a document that serves as proof of authorization to enter a restricted area. (document d’autorisation)
escort officer means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a peace officer; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any person authorized by the federal government or a provincial government or any of their agencies to escort a person in custody on a flight. (agent d’escorte)

Definition.Text: exigent circumstances means circumstances beyond a border services officer’s or a US preclearance officer’s control in which the officer’s continued presence is required to

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: preserve the integrity of an examination or investigation that is underway; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevent an imminent danger to human life or serious damage to property. (situation d’urgence)

Definition.Text: firearm has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Criminal Code. (arme à feu)
general list of prohibited items means Part 1 of TP 14628, which lists or describes goods that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: could pose a threat to aviation security;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: are prohibited as carry-on baggage by the governments of other countries; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: are identified by the International Civil Aviation Organization as items that must never be carried in the cabin of an aircraft or taken into a restricted area. (liste générale des articles interdits)

Definition.Text: incendiary device means an object, other than a match or pocket lighter, that is fabricated with combustible materials and is designed to inflict burn injuries on individuals or to cause fire damage to property. (engin incendiaire)
inspector means a person who is authorized by the Minister to carry out an inspection under subsection 8.7(1) of the Act. (inspecteur)

key means a key, card or other device, including a functionality that can be added to a restricted area identity card, that is designed to allow access to a restricted area and that is issued to an individual by, or under the authority of, the operator of an aerodrome. (clé)
Minister means the Minister of Transport. (ministre)
non-consolidated cargo means a cargo shipment that originates from a single shipper. (fret non groupé)

non-passenger screening checkpoint means a restricted area access point or a location inside a restricted area where persons other than passengers are screened or can be screened. (point de contrôle des non-passagers)
operator of an aerodrome means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aerodrome that is not an airport, the person in charge of the aerodrome, and includes an employee, an agent or a representative of the person in charge of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an airport, the holder of the Canadian aviation document issued in respect of the airport or the person in charge of the airport, and includes an employee, an agent or a representative of the holder of the Canadian aviation document; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an aerodrome or part of an aerodrome that is operated by the Minister of National Defence and used by an air carrier, the person in charge of commercial air service operations at the aerodrome. (exploitant d’un aérodrome)

Definition.Text: operator of an aircraft means the person who has possession of the aircraft as owner, lessee or otherwise. (utilisateur d’un aéronef)
passenger screening checkpoint means a screening checkpoint that is intended primarily for the screening of departing passengers. (point de contrôle des passagers)
peace officer means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a member of the Correctional Service of Canada who is designated as a peace officer under Part I of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act and any other officer or permanent employee of a prison, other than a penitentiary as defined in Part I of that Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, a police officer or a police constable;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: any person who is designated by the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, the Commissioner of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police or a provincial minister as a peace officer for the purpose of the preservation and maintenance of the public peace at an aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an officer who is enforcing any provision of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, or of any regulations, warrant, order or direction made under that Act, respecting the arrest, detention or removal from Canada of any person; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an officer or non-commissioned member of the Canadian Forces who is appointed as a member of the military police under regulations for the purposes of section 156 of the National Defence Act. (agent de la paix)

Definition.Text: personal identification code means a series or combination of numbers, letters or other characters that is chosen by a person or that is assigned to a person by, or under the authority of, the operator of an aerodrome and that, when entered into or placed near mechanical or electronic equipment on or near a door, gate or other device, unlocks or releases the door, gate or other device and allows access to a restricted area. (code d’identification personnel)
primary security line means the boundary between a restricted area and a non-restricted area at an aerodrome. (première ligne de sûreté)

primary security line partner means a business, organization or non-profit group — other than the operator of an aerodrome, CATSA, a government department or agency or the police service with jurisdiction at an aerodrome — that occupies an area that is on an aerodrome’s primary security line and that includes a restricted area access point. This definition includes, but is not limited to, a commercial lessee of the operator of an aerodrome. (partenaire de la première ligne de sûreté)
regulatory requirement means a requirement of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: these Regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: any other aviation security regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a security measure;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an interim order; or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a ministerial order. (exigence réglementaire)

Definition.Text: restricted area means any part of an aerodrome that is designated as a restricted area by the operator of the aerodrome in accordance with a regulatory requirement. (zone réglementée)
restricted area access point means an opening in a security barrier that allows access to a restricted area. (point d’accès aux zones réglementées)

restricted area identity card means a restricted area pass that is issued by or under the authority of the operator of an aerodrome and that can be automatically verified by an identity verification system maintained by CATSA under section 56. (carte d’identité de zone réglementée)

restricted area pass means a pass issued by or under the authority of the operator of an aerodrome to a person who requires ongoing access to restricted areas as part of the person’s employment. (laissez-passer de zone réglementée)
screening authority means, as the context requires,

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: CATSA;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a screening contractor as defined in section 2 of the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority Act; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a screening officer. (administration de contrôle)

Definition.Text: screening officer has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority Act. (agent de contrôle)
security barrier means a physical structure or natural feature used to prevent or deter access by unauthorized persons to a restricted area. (enceinte de sûreté)

sensitive information respecting aviation security means information — including information respecting risks, threats, vulnerabilities, systems, equipment, controls and procedures as well as plans and technical drawings — that could be used to exploit or create a vulnerability or to facilitate an act or attempted act of unlawful interference with civil aviation. (renseignements délicats relatifs à la sûreté aérienne)

specific list of prohibited items means Part 2 of TP 14628, which lists flights or classes of flights that require additional screening for reasons respecting elevated threat conditions or respecting the harmonization of screening rules and which lists or describes, for each flight or class of flight, goods that are supplemental to the goods listed or described in the general list of prohibited items. (liste spécifique des articles interdits)
sterile area means a restricted area, including any passenger loading bridge attached to it, that is used to segregate the following persons from other persons at an aerodrome:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: passengers who have been screened;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: passengers who are exempted from screening in accordance with an aviation security regulation, a security measure, an emergency direction or an interim order; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: other persons who are authorized to be in the area by the operator of the aerodrome. (zone stérile)

Definition.Text: threat item means any of the following goods that are in a shipment of cargo but are not listed on the air waybill or other similar control document issued in respect of that cargo:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an explosive substance;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an incendiary device;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a component of an explosive device or incendiary device; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: any other good that could pose a threat to aviation security. (article dangereux)

Definition.Text: TP 14628 means the document entitled Prohibited Items List, published by the Department of Transport in March 2011, as amended from time to time. (TP 14628)

US inspection agency means the entity responsible for carrying out responsibilities relating to the importation of goods, immigration, agriculture and public health and safety in order to determine whether a person or goods bound for the United States is or are admissible. (organisme d’inspection des États-Unis)
US inspection agency ammunition means ammunition that is provided to US preclearance officers by the US inspection agency. (munitions d’organisme d’inspection des États-Unis)

US inspection agency firearm means a firearm that is provided to US preclearance officers by the US inspection agency and that is loaded with US inspection agency ammunition or is unloaded. (arme à feu d’organisme d’inspection des États-Unis)
US preclearance officer has the meaning assigned to the definition preclearance officer in section 5 of the Preclearance Act, 2016. (contrôleur des États-Unis)
weapon has the same meaning as in section 2 of the Criminal Code. (arme)

Section.Text: This Part sets out requirements for screening officers, screening authorities and persons who are subject to screening. This Part is also a supplement to section 4.85 of the Act, which sets out several prohibitions respecting screening.

This Part applies in respect of aerodromes listed in the schedule to the CATSA Aerodrome Designation Regulations and in respect of any other place designated by the Minister under subsection 6(1.1) of the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority Act.

Subsection.Text: A screening authority must not permit a screening officer to screen persons or goods unless the screening officer

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is at least 18 years of age;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: is able to communicate effectively both orally and in writing in one or both official languages;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: has a security clearance;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: has taken the training referred to in section 20 and, if applicable, the ongoing training referred to in section 23;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: has successfully completed the evaluation in accordance with section 22 and, if applicable, subsection 23(4), demonstrating their competence in the carrying out of their screening duties;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: is certified by the screening authority as meeting the requirements referred to in paragraphs (a) to (f); and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: is designated by the Minister under section 4.84 of the Act.

Subsection.Text: The screening authority must ensure that any person who acts or will act as a screening officer for it or on its behalf meets the requirements set out in subsection (1).

Subsection.MarginalNote: Requalification — absence of more than a month
Subsection.Text: If the screening officer is absent from work for more than one month but less than 18 months, the screening authority must ensure that, before the screening officer resumes their duties, the screening officer is evaluated and takes any necessary training on the training elements set out in section 20 to ensure their competency.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Requalification — absence of 18 months or more
Subsection.Text: If the screening officer is absent from work for 18 months or more, the screening authority must ensure that the screening officer takes the training referred to in section 20 and is then evaluated to ensure their competency before they resume their duties.
The screening authority must cancel the certification granted to a person in accordance with paragraph 5(1)(g) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person ceases to be employed as a screening officer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person no longer meets the requirements set out in section 5 to conduct screening; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s designation is cancelled by the Minister.

Subsection.Text: The screening authority must notify the Minister when a screening officer’s certification is cancelled under paragraph (1)(a) or (b).
The screening authority must take corrective actions if a screening officer is unable to carry out their screening duties effectively.
The corrective actions must include a plan that addresses any screening deficiencies.
The screening authority must evaluate the screening officer to ensure the screening officer’s competency to carry out their duties effectively before they resume their duties.
The screening authority must create a training and certification record for each screening officer and make it available to the Minister on reasonable notice given by the Minister.
The screening authority must keep the records for at least 90 days after the day on which the screening officer ceases to be employed.

Section.Text: At the airports that are listed in Schedule 1 and at all aerodromes where there is a significant demand for services in either official language within the meaning of the Official Languages (Communications with and Services to the Public) Regulations, a screening authority must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: carry out screening by means that allow effective communication with members of the public in the official language of their choice; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: provide in both official languages any printed or pre-recorded material that is used in respect of screening.

Heading.TitleText: Carriage of Weapons, Explosive Substances and Incendiary Devices During Screening

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a person must not present themselves for a screening or submit goods in their possession or control for a screening while they are carrying or have access to a weapon, an explosive substance or an incendiary device.

A person who is permitted under subsection 78(2) to carry, transport or have access to a weapon, an explosive substance or an incendiary device may present themselves for a screening or submit goods in their possession or control for a screening while they are carrying or have access to that weapon, substance or device.

If a screening authority is notified by an air carrier that a peace officer will be carrying or will have access to a firearm on board an aircraft, the screening authority must notify all the screening officers with whom the peace officer will come into contact that the peace officer will be carrying or will have access to a firearm on board the aircraft.
If the peace officer is authorized by the air carrier under section 531, the peace officer must present the identification and the form referred to in that section to the screening officers.
For the purposes of sections 8.3 and 8.4, required identification means

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: one piece of valid government-issued photo identification that shows the holder’s name and date of birth;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: two pieces of valid government-issued identification, at least one of which shows the holder’s name and date of birth; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a restricted area identity card.

Subsection.Text: A document issued by a government for the purposes of fishing, hunting or boating is not required identification.

A screening authority must not allow a person to pass beyond a passenger screening checkpoint into a sterile area unless the screening authority screens the person, in accordance with these Regulations and any applicable security measure, emergency direction or interim order, by looking at the person, and in particular their entire face, to determine if they appear to be 18 years of age or older.

A screening authority must not allow a person referred to in subsection (1) who appears to be 18 years of age or older to pass beyond a passenger screening checkpoint into a sterile area unless the screening authority screens the person

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by comparing the person, and in particular their entire face, against the required identification, if applicable; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: by comparing the name on the person’s document of entitlement with the name on the required identification.

Subsection.Text: If a person referred to in subsection 8.3(1) who appears to be 18 years of age or older presents documentation that is issued by a government or a police service and that attests to the loss or theft of the required identification, a screening authority must not allow the person to pass beyond a passenger screening checkpoint into a sterile area unless the screening authority

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: screens the person’s identity using alternative forms of identification; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: carries out an additional screening of the person, and of any goods in their possession or control, for goods listed or described in the general list of prohibited items.

Subsection.Text: Alternative forms of identification include but are not limited to employee identity cards, public transit passes and baptismal certificates.
A screening authority must not allow a person referred to in subsection 8.3(1) who appears to be 18 years of age or older to pass beyond a passenger screening checkpoint into a sterile area if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person presents a piece of photo identification and does not resemble the photograph;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person presents more than one form of identification and there is a significant discrepancy between those forms of identification; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: there is a significant discrepancy between the name on the identification presented by the person and the name on their document of entitlement.

Subsection.Text: Paragraph (1)(a) does not apply in respect of a person referred to in subsection 8.3(1) if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s appearance changed for medical reasons after the photograph was taken and the person presents the screening authority with a document signed by a health care professional and attesting to that fact; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the person’s face is bandaged for medical reasons and the person presents the screening authority with a document signed by a health care professional and attesting to that fact.

Subsection.Text: If an aviation security regulation, a security measure, an emergency direction or an interim order requires a person to be screened, a screening authority must not permit the person to pass beyond a screening checkpoint into a sterile area unless the screening authority ensures that the person is not in possession or control of any goods that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: are listed or described in the general list of prohibited items; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: pose an immediate threat to aviation security.

Subsection.Text: If the sterile area is for passengers for a flight or class of flight that is listed in the specific list of prohibited items, the screening authority must not permit the person to pass beyond a screening checkpoint into the area unless the screening authority also ensures that the person is not in possession or control of any goods that are listed or described in that list for that flight or class of flight.

Section.MarginalNote: Weapons, explosive substances and incendiary devices
Section.Text: A screening authority may permit a person in possession or control of a weapon, an explosive substance or an incendiary device to pass beyond a screening checkpoint into a sterile area if the person is carrying or has access to the weapon, explosive substance or incendiary device in accordance with these Regulations, a security measure, an emergency direction or an interim order.

A screening authority may permit a person in possession or control of goods listed or described in the general list of prohibited items to pass beyond a screening checkpoint into a sterile area if the goods are medically necessary and the person declares them to the screening authority.

If an aviation security regulation, a security measure, an emergency direction or an interim order requires a person or any goods in their possession or control to be screened, another person must not assist that person in circumventing the screening.

If a piece of checked baggage is locked or sealed, a screening authority is authorized to use force when it is necessary to gain access to the contents of the piece of checked baggage for the purposes of screening.

Subsection.Text: When a screening authority uses force to gain access to the contents of a piece of checked baggage that is being screened, the screening authority must notify the person who tendered the checked baggage that it was opened by force.
The screening authority must create a record of each instance in which force is used to gain access to the contents of a piece of checked baggage that is being screened.
The screening authority must keep the record for at least 180 days.
The screening authority must provide the record to the Minister on reasonable notice given by the Minister.

Section.Text: A screening authority at an aerodrome who is made aware of a threat against the aerodrome must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately notify the operator of the aerodrome of the nature of the threat; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assist the operator of the aerodrome in determining whether there is a threat that jeopardizes the security of the aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: A screening authority at an aerodrome must immediately notify the appropriate air carrier, the operator of the aerodrome, the appropriate police service and the Minister if a weapon, an explosive substance or an incendiary device is detected at a restricted area access point or in any other part of the aerodrome where the screening of persons or goods is carried out.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of a weapon, explosive substance or incendiary device that is permitted under subsection 78(2).

A screening authority at an aerodrome must immediately notify the appropriate air carrier, the operator of the aerodrome, the appropriate police service and the Minister if any of the following is detected in checked baggage:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a loaded firearm;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an explosive substance, other than ammunition; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an incendiary device.

Subsection.Text: A screening authority at an aerodrome must immediately notify the appropriate air carrier, the operator of the aerodrome and the Minister of any other aviation security incident that involves a peace officer at a restricted area access point or in any other part of the aerodrome where it carries out screening.

Section.Text: A screening authority must provide the Minister, on reasonable notice given by the Minister, with written or electronic records or any other information relevant to the security of its screening operations, including

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: information concerning the method of implementing a security measure, emergency direction or interim order that applies to the screening authority; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the nature of the screening operations related to a particular flight or aerodrome.

Section.Text: A screening authority must establish and implement in a consistent manner across Canada a training program for screening officers. The training program must be composed of both theoretical and practical training and

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: cover the responsibilities and duties of a screening officer, as well as screening processes;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: cover the safeguarding of civil aviation operations against acts of unlawful interference, as well as current and emerging aviation security threats and trends;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: cover the use of screening equipment, and include practical training using the screening equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: include on-the-job training provided and supervised by a person who has knowledge of and experience in screening.

Section.Text: The screening authority must ensure that an instructor who provides the training referred to in paragraphs 20(a) to (d)

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: is at least 18 years of age;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: is a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident as defined in subsection 2(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: has a security clearance;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: has specialized knowledge of aviation security screening operations;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: has successfully completed instructor training on aviation security and the screening elements to be taught; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: has knowledge of current and emerging aviation security threats and trends and of regulatory requirements related to screening.

Subsection.Text: The screening authority must evaluate a screening officer candidate who has taken the training referred to in section 20 based on the following criteria:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: knowledge of the elements referred to in paragraphs 20(a) and (b); and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the ability to operate screening equipment and apply the screening processes for persons and goods.

Subsection.Text: If the screening is to be carried out using X-ray equipment, the evaluation referred to in paragraph (1)(b) must contain an X-ray component that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the screening of goods that are listed or described in the general list of prohibited items, with an emphasis on explosive substances;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the screening of goods that are arranged in a way that creates various levels of difficulty in identifying them; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the use of X-ray image enhancement tools.

Subsection.Text: In order for a screening officer to maintain their knowledge and skills, the screening authority must have an ongoing training program that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: covers changes in screening processes, screening equipment and aviation security threats and trends; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: includes a review of any screening issues and gaps.

Subsection.Text: The program must set out the frequency of ongoing training.
The ongoing training must be provided by an instructor who meets the requirements set out in section 21.
The screening authority must evaluate the knowledge and skills of the screening officer as soon as feasible.

Section.Text: The screening authority must provide the Minister, on reasonable notice given by the Minister, with its screening officer training program and the examinations used for evaluations.

Subsection.Text: A screening authority must obtain the Minister’s approval before implementing any of the following measures:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the use, on a trial basis, of new screening equipment or software;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the modification of approved screening equipment or software; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the addition of new screening equipment or software.

Subsection.Text: The screening authority must include the following information in the request for approval for the purposes of subsection (1):

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons for the implementation of the measures and any supporting documentation from the manufacturer;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of any proposed modifications to approved screening equipment or software;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a list of the performance verification tools approved by the Minister that will be used; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: documentation demonstrating that the detection performance of any modified equipment is maintained or enhanced.

Subsection.Text: A screening authority must implement and maintain a process approved by the Minister for preventing the disclosure of sensitive information respecting aviation security when screening equipment or software is sold, destroyed or otherwise disposed of.
If the screening authority intends to amend the process, it must obtain the approval of the Minister before implementing the amended process.
CATSA must implement and maintain an identity verification system that is able to automatically verify

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that a person in possession of a restricted area identity card is the person to whom the card has been issued; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that the restricted area identity card is active or has been deactivated.

Subsection.Text: The verification referred to in paragraph (1)(a) must be carried out by an on-site comparison of the biometric data provided by the person and a biometric template stored on the restricted area identity card.

Section.Text: CATSA must regularly back up any database that it uses as part of the identity verification system.

Subsection.Text: CATSA is authorized to disclose to the Minister or the operator of an aerodrome any information that is necessary for the proper operation of the identity verification system.
CATSA must not collect, use, disclose or retain the identity of an applicant for a restricted area identity card or the identity of a person to whom a restricted area identity card has been issued.

If a biometric template created from a fingerprint image or iris image collected from an applicant for a restricted area identity card is disclosed to CATSA by the operator of an aerodrome, CATSA must not use the biometric template for a purpose other than

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: monitoring the quality of biometric templates; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: determining if a restricted area identity card is already active in respect of the applicant.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must notify the Minister if it determines that a restricted area identity card is already active in respect of an applicant.

CATSA must destroy any biometric template that is disclosed to it in connection with an application for a restricted area identity card as soon as feasible in accordance with the Access to Information Act, the Library and Archives of Canada Act, the Privacy Act and any regulations made under those Acts.

Section.Text: CATSA must take appropriate measures to protect information that is collected, used, retained or disclosed for the purposes of the identity verification system from loss or theft and from unauthorized access, use, disclosure, duplication or alteration.

CATSA must activate a restricted area identity card if the Minister informs CATSA that the applicant for the card has a security clearance and CATSA determines that no restricted area identity card is already active in respect of the applicant.
CATSA must immediately deactivate a restricted area identity card if the Minister or the operator of an aerodrome asks CATSA to deactivate the card.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must develop and maintain a business continuity plan — to be implemented in the event that it is unable to use the identity verification system — that sets out

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: how CATSA will maintain an equivalent level of security until normal operations are re-established, including the ability to meet the following objectives:

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: to receive security clearance information from the Minister,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: to activate and deactivate restricted area identity cards, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: to allow the operator of an aerodrome to verify that a restricted area identity card is active or has been deactivated; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: how CATSA will re-establish normal operations.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must implement its business continuity plan and immediately notify the Minister and any affected operator of an aerodrome if it discovers that it is unable to use the identity verification system for the operations set out in subparagraphs (1)(a)(i) to (iii).

CATSA must immediately notify the Minister and any affected operator of an aerodrome if it discovers that it will be unable, for more than 24 hours, to use the identity verification system for the operations set out in subparagraphs (1)(a)(i) to (iii) and must immediately inform the Minister and any affected operator of an aerodrome of how it will re-establish normal operations.
CATSA must make its business continuity plan available to the Minister on reasonable notice given by the Minister.
CATSA must keep updated records respecting

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: restricted area identity cards that have been activated;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: restricted area identity cards that have been deactivated;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: deactivated restricted area identity cards that have not been retrieved;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: restricted area identity cards that have been reported as lost or stolen; and

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: blank restricted area identity cards distributed to operators of aerodromes.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must provide the Minister with the records on reasonable notice given by the Minister.

CATSA must establish and implement a security program in order to safeguard information, equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities and all other assets related to screening operations.
As part of its security program, CATSA must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: develop a security policy statement that establishes an overall security commitment and direction and sets out the security objectives;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: establish and implement a security awareness program that promotes a culture of vigilance among its employees;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: conduct a security risk assessment in accordance with section 69;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: assess risk information and disseminate it within its organization for the purpose of facilitating informed decision-making about security;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: establish a strategic security plan in accordance with section 73;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: identify the security official referred to in subsection (3);

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: subject to section 31, establish and implement a process for receiving, identifying, retaining, disclosing and disposing of sensitive information respecting aviation security in order to protect the information from unauthorized access; and

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: establish and implement a process for responding to security incidents and breaches.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must have, at all times, at least one security official or acting security official who is responsible for acting as the principal contact between CATSA and the Minister with respect to the security program.
CATSA must keep

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: documentation related to its security risk assessment and any review of it for at least five years;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: documentation related to its strategic security plan and any amendment to it for at least five years; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: all other documentation related to its security program for at least two years.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must make the documentation available to the Minister on reasonable notice given by the Minister.

Section.Text: CATSA must amend its security program if it identifies a security risk that is not addressed by the program.
CATSA must be an active member of an aerodrome’s multi-agency advisory committee referred to in sections 196 and 353.

CATSA must have a security risk assessment that identifies and assesses the risks in respect of information, equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities and all other assets related to screening operations and that includes the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a threat assessment that evaluates the probability of a disruption to security screening services caused by an unauthorized access or an act or attempted act of unlawful interference;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a criticality assessment that prioritizes the information, equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities and all other assets related to screening operations that most require protection from acts and attempted acts of unlawful interference;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a vulnerability assessment that considers the extent to which information, equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities and all other assets related to screening operations are susceptible to loss or damage; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an impact assessment that, at a minimum, measures the consequences of a security screening incident or potential security screening incident in terms of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: a decrease in public safety and security,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: financial and economic loss, and

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: a loss of public confidence.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must submit its initial security risk assessment to the Minister for approval.
CATSA must submit a new security risk assessment to the Minister within five years after the date of the most recent approval.
CATSA must conduct a review of its security risk assessment at least once a year.
CATSA must also conduct a review of its security risk assessment if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it acquires new equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities or any other new assets related to screening operations;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: it makes changes to security screening operations that could affect information, equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities or any other assets related to screening operations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a change in regulatory requirements could affect information, equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities or any other assets related to screening operations; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: it identifies a vulnerability that is not addressed in the assessment or the Minister identifies such a vulnerability to CATSA.

Subsection.Text: For greater certainty, a review conducted under subsection (2) counts as a review required under subsection (1).
When CATSA conducts a review of its security risk assessment, it must document

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: any decision to amend or to not amend the assessment or the risk-management strategy;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the reasons for that decision; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the factors that were taken into consideration in making that decision.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must notify the Minister if, as a result of a review of its security risk assessment, it amends the assessment

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to include a new medium to high risk; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to raise or lower the level of a risk within the medium to high range.

Section.Text: The Minister must approve a security risk assessment submitted by CATSA if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the assessment meets the requirements of section 69;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the assessment has been reviewed by an executive within CATSA who is responsible for security;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: CATSA has considered all available and relevant information; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: CATSA has not overlooked a security risk that could compromise information, equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities or any other assets related to screening operations.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must establish a strategic security plan that

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: summarizes its strategy to prepare for, detect, prevent, respond to and recover from threats identified in the security risk assessment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: includes a risk-management strategy that addresses the medium to high security risks identified and prioritized in its security risk assessment.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must submit its strategic security plan to the Minister for approval.
The Minister must approve a strategic security plan submitted by CATSA if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the plan meets the requirements of subsection (1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the plan has been reviewed by an executive within CATSA who is responsible for security;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the plan is likely to enable CATSA to prepare for, detect, prevent, respond to and recover from an unauthorized access to or acts or attempted acts of unlawful interference with information, equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities or any other assets related to screening operations;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the risk-management strategy is in proportion to the risks it addresses;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: CATSA has not overlooked a security risk that could compromise information, equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities or any other assets related to screening operations; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the plan can be implemented without compromising security.

Subsection.Text: CATSA must, as soon as its strategic security plan is approved, implement its risk-management strategy.
CATSA may amend its strategic security plan at any time, but must do so if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the plan does not reflect CATSA’s most recent security risk assessment;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister informs CATSA that there is a change in the threat environment that could result in a new or unaddressed medium to high risk to information, equipment, information technology infrastructure, facilities or any other assets related to screening operations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: CATSA identifies a deficiency in the plan; or

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the Minister informs CATSA that its risk-management strategy is not in proportion to a risk set out in its security risk assessment.

Subsection.Text: If CATSA amends its strategic security plan, it must document

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the reason for the amendment; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the factors that were taken into consideration in making that amendment.

Subsection.Text: If CATSA amends its strategic security plan, it must, as soon as possible, submit the amendment to the Minister for approval.
The Minister must approve an amendment if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an amendment to the summary required under paragraph 73(1)(a), the conditions set out in paragraphs 73(3)(a) to (c) have been met; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of an amendment to the risk-management strategy required under paragraph 73(1)(b), the conditions set out in paragraphs 73(3)(a) to (f) have been met.

Subsection.Text: If CATSA amends its risk-management strategy, it must implement the amended version of the strategy once it is approved by the Minister.

Section.Text: A person other than the Minister must not disclose security-sensitive information that is created or used under this Part unless the disclosure is required by law or is necessary to comply or facilitate compliance with the aviation security provisions of the Act, regulatory requirements or the requirements of an emergency direction.

Heading.Label: PART 3
Heading.TitleText: Weapons, Explosive Substances and Incendiary Devices

Section.Text: This Part sets out prohibitions respecting weapons, explosive substances and incendiary devices at aerodromes and on board aircraft. This Part also sets out exceptions to those prohibitions.
A person must not sell or offer for sale any of the following goods in a restricted area:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a weapon;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a model or replica of a weapon;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an explosive substance; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an incendiary device.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (2), a person must not carry, transport or have access to a weapon, an explosive substance or an incendiary device at an aerodrome.

Subsection.Text: An employee of a federal or provincial department or agency who is engaged in wildlife control, and who carries, transports or has access to an unloaded firearm at an aerodrome, must not consume any alcoholic beverage.

For the purposes of subsection (2), commercial office means an area of a customs office designated under section 5 of the Customs Act that is used primarily for the reporting, examination and release under that Act of commercial goods, as defined in section 2 of the Reporting of Imported Goods Regulations.

The agency that employs the person described in items 10 to 21, column 1, of the table to subsection 78(2) must ensure that that person meets the conditions set out in column 3 of those items and, in the case where the agency identifies a failure to comply with a condition, it must immediately take corrective actions to prevent the recurrence of the failure.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Records — failure to comply with condition
Subsection.Text: Each time the agency identifies a failure to comply with a condition, it must create a record that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the failure occurred;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the failure; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the corrective actions that were taken to prevent the recurrence of the failure.

Subsection.Text: The agency must provide the Minister with the records on reasonable notice given by the Minister.

Each time a person described in item 12 or 19, column 1, of the table to subsection 78(2) exceeds, due to exigent circumstances, the one-hour period referred to in column 3, the agency that employs that person must create a record that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the date on which the one-hour period was exceeded;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the amount of time by which the one-hour period was exceeded; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a description of the exigent circumstances.

Subsection.Text: The agency must provide the Minister with the records on reasonable notice given by the Minister.
Subject to subsections (2.1) to (4), a person must not carry or have access to a weapon on board an aircraft.
Subject to subsections (2.1) to (2.4), (3.1) and (4), a person other than an air carrier must not carry or have access to an explosive substance or incendiary device on board an aircraft.
A Canadian in-flight security officer who is acting in the course of their duties may carry or have access to a loaded firearm on board an aircraft operated by an air carrier.

A border services officer who is acting in the course of their duties may carry or have access to defensive equipment, an agency firearm and ammunition on board an aircraft that is on the ground at an aerodrome.

A US preclearance officer who is exercising their powers or performing their duties or functions under the Preclearance Act, 2016 may carry or have access to defensive equipment, a US inspection agency firearm and US inspection agency ammunition on board an aircraft that is on the ground at an aerodrome.

A person described in item 22, column 1, of the table to subsection 78(2) who is acting in the course of their duties may carry or have access to defensive equipment, a loaded agency firearm and ammunition on board an aircraft that is on the ground at an aerodrome.
The following persons may carry or have access to an unloaded firearm on board an aircraft operated by an air carrier:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a peace officer who is authorized by the air carrier under section 531;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the pilot-in-command of the aircraft if authorized by the air carrier under subsection 533(1); and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an employee of a federal or provincial department or agency who is engaged in wildlife control and who is authorized by the air carrier under subsection 533(1).

Subsection.Text: A person described in item 22, column 1, of the table to subsection 78(2) may carry or have access to defensive equipment, a loaded agency firearm and ammunition on board an aircraft, if authorized by the operator of the aircraft under section 533.1.

The pilot-in-command of an aircraft operated by a person other than an air carrier may carry or have access to an unloaded firearm and ammunition on board the aircraft if authorized by the operator of the aircraft under subsection 533(2).
The following persons must not consume any alcoholic beverage if they are on board an aircraft and are carrying or have access to an unloaded firearm:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a peace officer; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an employee of a federal or provincial department or agency who is engaged in wildlife control.

Subsection.Text: Subject to subsection (3), a person must not transport any of the following goods on board an aircraft operated by an air carrier or tender them for transportation by an air carrier:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a loaded firearm;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an explosive substance other than ammunition; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: an incendiary device.

Subsection.Text: A person must not tender an unloaded firearm to an air carrier for subsequent acceptance and transportation unless the person declares to the air carrier that the firearm is unloaded.

A person may transport an explosive substance or an incendiary device on board an aircraft operated by an air carrier, or tender it for transportation by an air carrier, if the person notifies the air carrier before the explosive substance or incendiary device arrives at the aerodrome.

Section.Text: A person at an aerodrome or on board an aircraft must not falsely declare

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the person is carrying a weapon, an explosive substance, an incendiary device or any other item that could be used to jeopardize the security of an aerodrome or aircraft or that such an item is contained in goods in the person’s possession or control or in goods that the person has tendered or is tendering for screening or transportation; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that another person at an aerodrome or on board an aircraft is carrying a weapon, an explosive substance, an incendiary device or any other item that could be used to jeopardize the security of an aerodrome or aircraft or that such an item is contained in goods in the other person’s possession or control or in goods that the other person has tendered or is tendering for screening or transportation.

Section.Text: This Part sets out the basic regulatory framework for security at aerodromes listed in Schedule 1.
This Part applies in respect of aerodromes listed in Schedule 1.
This Division completes and supplements the regulatory framework set out in Part 3.

Heading.TitleText: Authorization for Carriage of or Access to Explosive Substances and Incendiary Devices

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome may authorize a person to carry or have access to an explosive substance or an incendiary device at the aerodrome if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the explosive substance or incendiary device is to be used at the aerodrome

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: for excavation, demolition or construction work,

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: in fireworks displays,

Subparagraph.Label: (iii)
Subparagraph.Text: by persons operating explosives detection equipment or handling explosives detection dogs,

Subparagraph.Label: (iv)
Subparagraph.Text: by a police service, or

Subparagraph.Label: (v)
Subparagraph.Text: by military personnel; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has reasonable grounds to believe that the safety of the aerodrome and the safety of persons and aircraft at the aerodrome will not be jeopardized by the presence of the explosive substance or incendiary device.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must not permit goods listed or described in the general list of prohibited items or, as applicable, the specific list of prohibited items to be made available to persons in a sterile area.
Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of liquids, aerosols and gels that are made available to persons in accordance with a security measure.

Subsection (1) does not apply in respect of rounded, dull-blade knives and plastic knives that are made available to the customers of a concessionaire with the permission of the operator of the aerodrome.

Section.Text: This Division sets out the regulatory framework for dealing with threats and incidents at an aerodrome.

The operator of an aerodrome who is made aware of a threat against an aviation facility, or a part of the aerodrome, that is under the operator’s control must immediately determine whether there is a threat that jeopardizes the security of the facility or that part of the aerodrome.

Section.MarginalNote: Area under control of other person
Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome who is made aware of a threat against an aviation facility, or a part of the aerodrome, that is under the control of a person carrying on any activity at the aerodrome, other than the operator, must immediately

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: notify the person of the nature of the threat; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: determine whether there is a threat that jeopardizes the security of the aerodrome.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome who determines that there is a threat that jeopardizes the security of the aerodrome must immediately take all of the measures necessary to ensure the safety of the aerodrome and persons at the aerodrome, including informing the appropriate police service of the nature of the threat.
A person, other than a screening authority, who is carrying on any activity at an aerodrome and who is made aware of a threat against the aerodrome must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: immediately notify the operator of the aerodrome of the nature of the threat; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: assist the operator of the aerodrome in determining whether there is a threat that jeopardizes the security of the aerodrome.

Section.Text: If it is determined under paragraph 15(b), 90(b) or 92(b) that there is a threat that jeopardizes the security of an aerodrome, the operator of the aerodrome must immediately take all of the measures necessary to ensure the safety of the aerodrome and persons at the aerodrome, including informing the appropriate police service of the nature of the threat.
The operator of an aerodrome must immediately notify the Minister when any of the following incidents occur:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the discovery, at the aerodrome, of a weapon, explosive substance or incendiary device that is not permitted under subsection 78(2);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: an explosion at the aerodrome, unless the explosion is known to be the result of an accident, excavation, demolition or construction work, or the use of fireworks displays;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a threat against the aerodrome; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an aviation security incident that involves a peace officer anywhere at the aerodrome other than areas under an air carrier’s control.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must provide the Minister with written notice of any new commercial air service that is to begin at an air terminal building.
This Division sets out requirements respecting the implementation of additional safeguards in the event of heightened risk conditions.
If the AVSEC level is raised or maintained above level 1 for an aerodrome or any part of an aerodrome, the operator of the aerodrome must immediately take the following actions:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: determine which additional safeguards are likely to mitigate the heightened risk condition;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: notify any persons or organizations that have aviation security roles and responsibilities at the aerodrome and are affected by the heightened risk condition;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: implement or continue to implement the additional safeguards; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: notify the Minister of the additional safeguards that are being or will be implemented.

Section.Text: When the AVSEC level is lowered for an aerodrome or any part of an aerodrome, the operator of the aerodrome must immediately notify the persons and organizations that were notified under paragraph 97(b).
For greater certainty, nothing in these Regulations authorizes the operator of an aerodrome to implement additional safeguards that are inconsistent with the operator’s legal powers and obligations.
This Division sets out requirements respecting aerodrome security personnel and other persons who are assigned aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities at an aerodrome.
A security official of an aerodrome is an individual who is responsible for

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: coordinating and overseeing security controls and procedures at the aerodrome; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: acting as the principal contact between the operator of the aerodrome and the Minister with respect to security matters, including the airport security program.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must have, at all times, at least one security official or acting security official.
The operator of the aerodrome must provide the Minister with

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the name of each security official and acting security official; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: 24-hour contact information for those officials.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that a member of the aerodrome security personnel does not carry out an aerodrome-related security role or responsibility at the aerodrome unless the member has received initial training in relation to that role or responsibility.

Initial training for aerodrome security personnel must include instruction and evaluation in relation to the topics set out below that are relevant to the aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities of the personnel:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: international instruments respecting aviation security, the aviation security provisions of the Act and regulatory requirements;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the security controls and procedures at the aerodrome where the personnel are employed;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: systems and equipment at the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an overview of threats to aviation security and acts or attempted acts of unlawful interference with civil aviation;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: the recognition of goods that are listed or described in TP 14628 or that pose an immediate threat to aviation security; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: the actions to be taken by the personnel in response to a threat to aviation security or an act or attempted act of unlawful interference with civil aviation.

Subsection.Text: Aerodrome security personnel who are employed at the aerodrome on the day on which this section comes into force are exempted from initial training in relation to any topic for which they have already received training.
The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that aerodrome security personnel receive follow-up training when any of the following circumstances arise:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a change is made in the aviation security provisions of the Act or in regulatory requirements and the change is relevant to the aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities of the personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a change is made in the security controls and procedures at the aerodrome where the personnel are employed and the change is relevant to the aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities of the personnel;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a new or modified action is to be taken by the personnel in response to a threat to aviation security or an act or attempted act of unlawful interference with civil aviation; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a significant risk or an emerging trend in aviation security is identified to the operator by the Minister and the risk or trend is relevant to the aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities of the personnel.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that a member of the aerodrome security personnel receives follow-up training when the Minister or the operator identifies a shortcoming in the member’s performance when the member is carrying out security controls or following security procedures at the aerodrome.
Follow-up training must include

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a review of any initial-training element related to the circumstance set out in subsection (1) or (2) that gave rise to the follow-up training; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: instruction and evaluation in relation to that circumstance.

Section.Text: If, at an aerodrome, the initial or follow-up training of aerodrome security personnel includes on-the-job training, the operator of the aerodrome must ensure that the on-the-job training is provided by a person who has received that same training or has significant experience working as a member of the aerodrome security personnel at an aerodrome listed in Schedule 1.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that, for each individual who receives training in accordance with section 115 or 116, there is a training record that includes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the individual’s employee group or contractor group, if applicable, and a description of the individual’s aerodrome-related security roles and responsibilities;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a description of all the training that the individual has received in accordance with section 115 or 116; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: evaluation results for all the training that the individual has received in accordance with section 115 or 116.

Subsection.Text: The operator of the aerodrome must keep the training record for at least two years.
The operator of the aerodrome must make the training record available to the Minister on reasonable notice given by the Minister.

Section.Text: This Division sets out requirements respecting the facilitation of screening operations at an aerodrome.
The operator of an aerodrome must make facilities available for passenger screening checkpoints and must make at least one facility available for the private screening of passengers.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must post a notice at each passenger screening checkpoint stating that it is an offence for a person at the aerodrome to falsely declare

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: that the person is carrying a weapon, an explosive substance, an incendiary device or any other item that could be used to jeopardize the security of an aerodrome or aircraft, or that such an item is contained in goods in the person’s possession or control or in goods that the person has tendered or is tendering for screening or transportation; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: that another person who is at an aerodrome or on board an aircraft is carrying a weapon, an explosive substance, an incendiary device or any other item that could be used to jeopardize the security of an aerodrome or aircraft, or that such an item is contained in goods in the other person’s possession or control or in goods that the other person has tendered or is tendering for screening or transportation.

Subsection.Text: The notice must be clearly visible and be in at least both official languages.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must make facilities available for non-passenger screening checkpoints at restricted area access points and at locations inside restricted areas.

The operator of an aerodrome must, in accordance with a security measure, ensure that non-passengers enter a restricted area at the aerodrome only through a restricted area access point where screening is carried out.
The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that non-passengers who access sterile areas are notified of any restrictions on the possession of liquids, aerosols or gels in sterile areas.
The operator of an aerodrome must make facilities available for the screening of checked baggage and baggage intended to be checked baggage.

If the operator of an aerodrome is responsible for a baggage handling system, the operator must not make any change to the system that may affect screening operations unless the change is agreed to by CATSA.
This Division sets out the regulatory framework for the protection of security-sensitive areas of aerodromes.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must post signs on the outside of each restricted area access point and each security barrier. Each sign must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: be in at least both official languages;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: identify the restricted area as a restricted area; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: state that access to the area is restricted to authorized persons.

Subsection.Text: The signs posted on a security barrier must be no more than 150 m apart.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that each restricted area access point that allows access from a non-restricted area to a restricted area has an access control system consisting of one or more of the following elements:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: surveillance by a person authorized by the operator of the aerodrome to control access to the restricted area;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: manual locking equipment; and

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: automated access control equipment.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must ensure that each restricted area access point that is located between an air terminal building and a passenger loading bridge has a door that can be locked.
A person must not enter a restricted area at an aerodrome except through a restricted area access point.
The operator of an aerodrome must take measures to prevent unauthorized access to a baggage handling system that is in a restricted area.

Heading.TitleText: Doors, Gates, Emergency Exits and Other Devices

Section.MarginalNote: Duty to close and lock — operators

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must close and lock any door, gate or other device, other than an emergency exit, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has control of and responsibility for the door, gate or other device; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the door, gate or other device allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area.

Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must institute a system, on or near an emergency exit, that prevents access by unauthorized persons to a restricted area, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the operator has control of and responsibility for the emergency exit; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the emergency exit allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area.

Section.MarginalNote: Duty to close and lock — partners and lessees

Subsection.Text: A primary security line partner, or a lessee other than a primary security line partner, at an aerodrome must close and lock any door, gate or other device, other than an emergency exit, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the partner or lessee has control of and responsibility for the door, gate or other device; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the door, gate or other device allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area.

Subsection.Text: A primary security line partner who occupies an area on an aerodrome’s primary security line must institute a system, on or near an emergency exit, that prevents access by unauthorized persons to a restricted area, if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the partner has control of and responsibility for the emergency exit; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the emergency exit allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area.

Section.Text: Any person at an aerodrome who has temporary use or control of a door, gate or other device that allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area must prevent access to or from the restricted area by unauthorized persons.
Unless an authorized person is controlling access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area at an aerodrome, a person who enters or leaves the restricted area must

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: lock the door, gate or other device that allows access to or from the restricted area; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: prevent access to or from the restricted area by unauthorized persons while the door, gate or other device is open or unlocked.

Section.Text: A person at an aerodrome must not prevent a door, gate or other device, other than an emergency exit, that allows access between a restricted area and a non-restricted area from being locked.
A person at an aerodrome must not open any door that is designated as an emergency exit and that is also a restricted area access point unless

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the person is authorized by the operator of the aerodrome to open it; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: there is an emergency.

Subsection.Text: If a person has been given notice, orally, in writing or by a sign, that access to a part of an aerodrome is prohibited or is limited to authorized persons, the person must not enter or remain in that part of the aerodrome without authorization.
The operator of an aerodrome may authorize a person to enter or remain in a restricted area if the requirements of Divisions 6 to 8 are met.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Non-public areas other than restricted areas
Subsection.Text: The operator of an aerodrome may authorize a person to enter or remain in a part of the aerodrome that is not a public area but is not a restricted area if the safety of the aerodrome, persons at the aerodrome and aircraft is not jeopardized.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Non-public areas other than restricted areas
Subsection.Text: A lessee at an aerodrome who has the use of, or is responsible for, a part of the aerodrome that is not a public area but is not a restricted area may authorize a person to enter or remain in that part of the aerodrome if the safety of the aerodrome, persons at the aerodrome and aircraft is not jeopardized.

Section.Text: The operator of an aerodrome must allow an inspector to enter or remain in a restricted area if the inspector is acting in the course of their employment and presents their credentials.
This Division sets out provisions respecting documents of entitlement. Requirements respecting the issue and use of restricted area identity cards are set out in Division 8.

Subsection.Text: Only the following documents are documents of entitlement at an aerodrome:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a restricted area identity card;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a temporary pass issued by the operator of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a boarding pass, a ticket, or any other document accepted by an air carrier that confirms the status of the person to whom it was issued as a passenger on a flight and that is approved by the operator of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a passenger escort form that is approved by the operator of the aerodrome;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a courtesy-lounge or conference-room pass that is issued by an air carrier and that is approved by the operator of the aerodrome; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
